#Text=Teotihuacan
#Text=Teotihuacan , also known as the City of the Gods , is an archeological site 40 km northeast of Mexico City .
#Text=Náhuatl for " the place where men became gods " , Teotihuacan is home to some of the largest ancient pyramids in the world .

column1: #Text=According to legend , it was here where the gods gathered to plan the creation of man .
#Text=The site is listed on the UNESCO World Heritage List .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Teotihuacan was the largest Pre-Columbian city in the Americas , reaching a total population of 150,000 at its height .
#Text=The name is also used to refer to the civilization this city dominated , which at its greatest extent included most of Mesoamerica .
#Text=Construction of Teotihuacán commenced around 300 BC , with the Pyramid of the Sun built by 150 BC .
#Text=Construction continued from 150 to 450 AD .
#Text=By the time the Spaniards arrived , this place was not used as a settlement anymore , but served as a spiritual and religious destination for the people of Tenochtitlan .
#Text=A lot of artifacts have wisely been moved to National Anthropological Museum , in Mexico City .
#Text=Elevation : 2,300m/7482f
#Text=By car ( or taxi )
#Text=It takes about 45 minutes from the Mexico City , city center if you use the toll highway .
#Text=It takes much longer , but more interesting , if you use the old free road .
#Text=There is a small fee for parking at the site .
#Text=A taxi may be prohibitively expensive , though sometimes tours with a car and driver/guide can be arranged for a reasonable fee if you want the convenience .
#Text=By bus
#Text=Buses to Teotihuacán leave from Mexico City about every half hour from two locations : ( outside Autobuses del Norte Metro station , Line 5 ) or from outside the ( Line 3 ) .
#Text=A one-way ticket will cost 50 pesos ( April 2019 ) .
#Text=From Terminal Autobuses del Norte , walk towards Gate 8 .
#Text=There is a ticket booth almost at the end of the concourse .
#Text=Check that your bus goes to the site entrance of Teotihuacán ruinas and not just to the town of San Juan Teotihuacán nearby .
#Text=From Potrero , exit the station and look for white buses that go to Piramides – they mean the pyramids of Teotihuacán .
#Text=The trip will take around an hour , and the buses run until about 18:00 .
#Text=When alighting the bus , check the last departure with the driver .
#Text=You will be dropped off and picked up at ( closest to the Temple of Quetzalcóatl ) .
#Text=By tour bus
#Text=Most travel agencies offer half or full day tours to the site , often combined with the Plaza de las Tres Culturas and the Basilica of Guadalupe , both of which are outside the city center .
#Text=It ’s a convenient way to combine the three , but note our comments above about getting to the site early .
#Text=The price is around 700 pesos for an adult .

#Text=As with guided tours everywhere in the world , these tours will waste much of your time by promoting gift shops , but they are still a convenient way to get here for Mexico City-based tourists .
#Text=Get around
#Text=There is an entrance fee of M$ 75 ( July 2017 ) to enter the park for non-Mexican visitors .

#Text=This is a large site , a lot of walking is required as there are few other ways to navigate the complex , unless you have a car , then you can freely drive around the perimeter ( if you are staying at the hotel in the park or heading to one of the many restaurants ) .
#Text=There are tractor-drawn wagons with seats and shelter that run on a schedule known only to them .
#Text=If you go by bus , they will deliver you to one spot , from which you will be required to walk to and from .
#Text=If you tire easily , pack light for this excursion ( i.e. , no backpacks , heavy purses , etc. )
#Text=There are plenty of friendly park police there , they may limit your driving around the site unless you are staying at the hotel .
#Text=Taxi drivers are not allowed to drive you around the site , you must have a destination , like a restaurant , inside of the park .
#Text=If you are adventurous and lucky , you may be able to rent a bicycle to ride around the perimeter on the cobble stone road ( a bit bouncy ) .
#Text=If you are visiting the site and do not have an opportunity to explore the perimeter where the shops , restaurants and old buildings are , you are missing out .
#Text=Just a little creativity should help you find some transportation inside of the complex .
#Text=The locals are very friendly and a few pesos will go a long way .
#Text=Try to at least find a ride around the perimeter to view the complex .
#Text=It will be worth the effort .
#Text=See
#Text=This site has many small pyramids , but essentially there are only four main attractions .
#Text=Pirámide del Sol ( Pyramid of the Sun ) .
#Text=The largest pyramid in the structure with an excellent view of the surrounding mountains .
#Text=Wear sunscreen , they do n't call it the Temple of the Sun for nothing .
#Text=Pirámide de la Luna ( Pyramid of the Moon ) .
#Text=A medium-sized pyramid off from the center of the complex .
#Text=Templo de Quetzalcoatl ( Temple of Quetzalcoatl ) .
#Text=One of the most sacred temples in the complex , this structure is decorated with many stone serpent heads .
#Text=Museo Teotihuacán .
#Text=The museum at the park with outstanding displays and a miniature recreation of the entire site .
#Text=Well worth the visit .
#Text=There are also many interesting constructions along the Avenue of the Dead which runs along the middle of the site , so do n't just walk from one temple to the other .

#Text=On the left side of the plaza in front of the Pyramid of the Moon are several areas including the , which includes the Palacio de los Jaguares ( Palace of the Jaguars ) and the Templo de los Caracoles Emplumados , with many wall paintings , sculptures , and underground rooms .
#Text=There are also some smaller structures surrounding the complex , no more than four or five meters in height .
#Text=A drive around the perimeter , on the road along the park will provide many surprises and is worth the trip .
#Text=Hitching a ride or even paying a few pesos for a ride will be worth the effort .
